ygData.subject: Re: [cantera] Re: Trouble running Fortran - Cantera interface
ygData.msgSnippet: I don t have Intel Fortran, so I m not going to be able to help much with this problem. Anyone else have experience with this?

I don't have Intel Fortran, so I'm not going to be able to help much 
with this problem. Anyone else have experience with this?

On Jun 20, 2005, at 9:10 PM, killakella2000 wrote:

> Dave.. Thank you for the response.  I now have Intel Visual Fortran
> 8 integrated to Visual Studio .NET.  However, I still cannot get the
> f77 demo program to work.  Here's what I've been through so far:
>
> When I open the original f77demo.dsw workspace file (found in the
> cantera-1.5.5/tools/templates/f77 folder) it asks me to convert to
> current Visual c++ project format.  I accept and it generates a
> f77demo.sln solution file which appears to be the equivalent of the
> old "workspaces".  I came across an option under the project menu
> to "extract compaq visual fortran project items".  I select this and
> it tells me I have both Fortran and C++ project files that need to
> be split into 2 projects.  I select the fortran project as the main
> project and c++ project as the "static library project that
> contributes object files to the link step of the main project."  I
> really thought I was getting somewhere when I found this..
>
> Both projects compile ok (once I change the directory of the header
> files as mentioned in a previous post).  When I try to build, I get
> a number of errors.  The first set are all similar to:
>
> libcd.lib(dbgheap.obj) : error LNK2005: __nh_malloc already defined
> in LIBC.lib(malloc.obj)
>
> I fixed these by setting the "ignore all default libraries" option
> under the f77demo project properties in the "linker" tab.  That
> hasn't quite fixed it.  Now when I build I get the following output:
>
>
> *********
>
>
> ------ Build started: Project: f77demo, Configuration: Debug|Win32 --
> ----
>
> Linking...
> Link /OUT:"Debug/f77demo.exe" /INCREMENTAL:NO /NOLOGO /NODEFAULTLIB /
> DEBUG /PDB:"Debug/f77demo.pdb" /SUBSYSTEM:CONSOLE kernel32.lib
> user32.lib gdi32.lib winspool.lib comdlg32.lib advapi32.lib
> shell32.lib ole32.lib oleaut32.lib uuid.lib odbc32.lib
> odbccp32.lib /MACHINE:I386 Debug/demo.obj "c:\Documents and
> Settings\rak2287\Desktop\f77 - run through\Debug\f77demo_lib.lib"
> Link: executing 'link'
> demo.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol __fltused
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol
> _for_set_reentrancy referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol
> _for_write_seq_lis referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol
> _NEWIDEALGASMIX@24 referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol
> _SETSTATE_TPX_STRING@16 referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol _TEMPERATURE@0
> referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol
> _for_write_seq_fmt referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol _PRESSURE@0
> referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol
> _for_write_seq_fmt_xmit referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol _DENSITY@0
> referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol
> _ENTHALPY_MOLE@0 referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol _ENTROPY_MOLE@0
> referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol _CP_MOLE@0
> referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol _EQUILIBRATE@8
> referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol _NREACTIONS@0
> referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol
> _GETFWDRATESOFPROGRESS@4 referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol
> _GETREVRATESOFPROGRESS@4 referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol
> _GETNETRATESOFPROGRESS@4 referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol
> _GETREACTIONEQN@12 referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol
> _for_emit_diagnostic referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol _VISCOSITY@0
> referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol
> _THERMALCONDUCTIVITY@0 referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol
> _GETMIXDIFFCOEFFS@4 referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol
> _for_write_seq_lis_xmit referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol _NSPECIES@0
> referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol
> _GETSPECIESNAME@12 referenced in function _MAIN__
> demo.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol _for_stop_core
> referenced in function _MAIN__
> LINK : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _mainCRTStartup
> Debug/f77demo.exe : fatal error LNK1120: 28 unresolved externals
>
>
> f77demo build failed.
>
> **************
>
>
> I am currently looking into what these different linker errors mean.
> However, like I mentioned before, my programming experience is
> pretty limited, so I thought I would post where I am at so far and
> hope that some of the more experienced Cantera users/programmers
> could point me in the right direction.  I would really appreciate
> anyone's help!
>
>
>
>
> --- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:
>> It would be easiest to use a Fortran compiler that is compatible
> with
>> Visual Studio .NET.  I think the Intel Fortran compiler is.  Since
> I
>> hardly ever use a PC anymore, perhaps someone else can better
> answer
>> this question.
>>
>> The f77 and f90 demo programs can all be built very easily on
> systems
>> that support the GNU tools (make, autoconf, etc.) and compilers
> (g++,
>> g77).  In my opinion, anyone planning to do serious work in
> Fortran (or
>> C++) with Cantera should at least consider getting a machine that
> runs
>> some unix-like operating system, such as linux or Mac OS X.  You
> can
>> get one for less than $1K, and don't need to buy expensive
> commercial
>> compilers.  Just a thought...
>>
>> Dave G.
>>
>>
>> On May 26, 2005, at 2:01 PM, killakella2000 wrote:
>>
>>> Hello.. I am trying to link my Fortran program to Cantera.  I
> built
>>> and installed Cantera from the source code using Visual C++ .NET,
>>> then I found the f77demo project under the source code download
>>> directory:  cantera-1.5.5\tools\templates\f77.
>>>
>>> I have Compaq Visual Fortran 6.6.a installed, which is what I
>>> created my original Fortran program on.  I tried opening and
>>> building the f77demo project, but the header files
> (idealgasmix.h,
>>> etc) could not be located.  I fixed this by changing the paths to
>>> the header files in the demo_ftnlib.cpp file to
>>> C:\Cantera\include\cantera\***.h, which is where the Cantera
>>> installation apparently puts them.  This fixed that problem, but
> now
>>> I get a bunch of "unresolved external symbol" errors.
>>>
>>> The readme file included in the f77demo project folder states
> that I
>>> can just open the project file and build it because Compaq Visual
>>> Fortran 6.0 and Microsoft Visual C++ 6.0 share a common
> development
>>> environment (Visual Studio).  Is this not the case with Visual
>>> C++ .NET?
>>>
>>> It is my understanding that I need to create the .obj file from
> the
>>> demo_ftnlib.cpp and run the included makefile to link that .obj
> file
>>> to the one created by the Fortran program.  If this is not what
> is
>>> supposed to happen, please let me know.  Obviously at this
> point, I
>>> am having trouble just creating the object file from the
>>> demo.ftnlib.cpp file.
>>>
>>> As you can probably tell, my programming experience is very
>>> limited.  If someone can point me in the right direction to get
> the
>>> demo program working it would be greatly appreciated!
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> Yahoo! Groups Links
>>>

>>>
